title: Clever feline correctly guesses cup ball owner mixes up
story: Snow the cat is filmed as he plays a cup and ball guessing game with his owner in Tokyo, JapanAnd after his owner switches the cups and muddles them up the cat is able to follow the one with the ball inside.When the cups stop moving the cat puts out a paw to pick the correct one.As he nonchalantly lays back on his bed or on the floor his owner brings the cup and ball to him.And despite not looking like he's paying a great deal of attention he is able to correctly guess which ball the cup is inside each time.          When the cups stop moving the cat puts out a paw to pick the cup with the ball inside         As he nonchalantly lays back on his bed or on the floor his owner brings the cup and ball to himAnd when Snow guesses right he is rewarded with a pat on his head and affection from his owner.To make the game harder Snow's owner increases the number of cups.But the clever feline is still able to guess correctly, even while picking between five cups.When hunting, cats track changes in their environment to anticipate how to get their prey successfully.This is why they are so adept at the cup and ball game.           Each time Snow correctly guesses he is rewarded with a pet on his head and affection from his owner

title: Botswana leopard flings impala catches mid air incredible sequence images
story: Share this article          Photographer Kevin Dooley, 57, took the stunning shots after trailing the leopard for a few days on the Mashatu reserve in the Tuli region of Botswana         Counter attack: The impala appears to launch a fightback as it lowers its horns towards the leopard as they rotate during the split-second strike         Desperate: The impala makes one last attempt to escape as it lands with its front hooves on the ground while the leopard remains airborne          Defeat: But the forsaken animal can do little as the predator sinks its teeth into its face, wraps its claws around and holds a vice-like grip         Hunted: The leopard, which had been a few days without food for her and her cub, finally hits the ground and begins to saviour its victim         Mr Dooley said: 'We were photographing this leopard with her cub. Both were showing signs of being hungry. Soon the leopard left the cub in the safety of a thick bush and headed down the river bed in search of food.' After the attack, he added: 'I could not believe my eyes'         Relax: The leopard holds on tight to the impala's face as it lies down on the dried up river bed. It appears to calm down as it realises there is no escape for its prey         Victory: The big cat looks majestic as it proudly sits on top of the impala it has just hunted. The beast will finally be able to feed its cub after days without food

title: Gary Lineker revealed BBCs highest earner three female stars 10
story: Share this article   The corporation says it is narrowing the gender pay gap after uproar among female stars who learned men were being paid much for for doing the same job.Jo Whiley was given £100,000 more  this year - up from £170,000 to £275,000. New Radio 2 Breakfast Show host Zoë Ball is earning £370,000, up from less than £150,000, and Sara Cox, who was vying for the top job on BBC radio, is up from £100,000 to £239,000. Zoe Ball's pay will rise significantly next year. She has only hosted the radio show since January after taking over from Chris Evans. A number of female news presenters also got huge windfalls, with Sophie Raworth now on more than £265,000, up from £205,000, Fiona Bruce on more than £255,000, up from around £185,000, and Emily Maitlis on more than £260,000, up from around £225,000. A number of high-profile men dropped out of the top 10, including Jeremy Vine, John Humphrys, Nicky Campbell and Nick Grimshaw. All four have seen their pay cut.  Jeremy Vine had £140,000 chopped from his salary while John Humphrys has lost £100,000, Steve Wright's pay dropped by £80,000 and Nicky Campbell is earning £60,000 less last year.But, in a statement posted by Today programme presenter Mishal Husain, the group BBC Women suggested it was too early to celebrate.'There has been some progress in the last two years, but many women at all levels of the BBC are locked into slow, inefficient and demoralising internal processes,' they said.'New equal pay cases are still emerging and staff are yet to have confidence that pay inequality is in the past.'                      BBC News presenters Sophie Raworth, Emily Maitlis and Fiona Bruce were among the women given bumper pay rises. Raworth earned up to £270,000, Maitlis up to £265,000 and Bruce up to £260,000                     Radio presenters Nick Grimshaw, Jeremy Vine and Nicky Campbell all dropped out of the BBC's top 10 earners list. Grimshaw's pay dropped from £400,000 to £310,000, Vine's dropped from £440,000 to £290,000 and Nicky Campbell's pay fell from £410,000 to £340,000BBC stars' TRUE pay revealed - after loophole conceals millions paid to top names - Mirror Online

title: Those knew Princess Diana best recall razor sharp wit
story: Share this article MICHAEL COLEFormer BBC royal correspondent, former director of Harrods‘Diana always had a great sense of fun and could rarely resist a bit of devilment. At a photo call in Switzerland, the Prince and Princess of Wales and the Duke and Duchess of York had skied down to have a group photograph. The princess took one look and decided it was all far too tame. “Let’s have a go,” she said to Fergie. The two royal wives proceeded to bang hips and push hard, each trying to dump the other in the snow. This horrified the royal husbands and they had to fight hard to stop them. The cameramen loved it.’JENNI RIVETTPersonal trainer‘I absolutely loved Diana’s sense of humour. She was always playing practical jokes. We had a strict routine at the Harbour Club gym, then suddenly one day she wanted to move to the stretching mat which I thought was odd. When I walked over to her I saw Hugh Grant and Simon Le Bon doing some stretching with her. She just wanted to be on the mat with them and show them how flexible she was. They were all laughing, she was showing them her various exercises and encouraging them to copy her.’JAYNE FINCHERPhotographer         Prince Charles and Diana sharing a laugh on a royal flight to Australia. Photographer Jayne Fincher said she 'had a really funny laugh too, it came right from her stomach'‘In the late 1980s, early 1990s before it all fell apart, when we were on long-haul flights she’d come back from first class and hang around the galley for a natter and a joke with whoever was around. She had a great sense of humour and was very good at remembering jokes. She always had a joke up her sleeve and she used to tell quite a few dirty ones. She had a really funny laugh too, it came right from her stomach. Once she saw something funny she was off. That was quite incredible at the time, because royals did not do that.’PATRICK JEPHSONFormer private secretary‘One evening in New York she was coming out of her suite at the Plaza Athenee and the head of her American Secret Service detail was waiting for her. He was very much smitten with the princess, I could tell. That evening she was wearing the most spectacular off-the-shoulder black evening gown. All you could really register was acres of lovely tanned royal skin. She leaned forward and prodded the secret service agent. Under his tuxedo you could see a shape under his shirt. She said, “What’s that?” and the guy said, “Bulletproof vest, Ma’am”. She stepped back in mock horror and said, “Shouldn’t I be wearing that?” That was just typical of her.’DR LILY HUA YUAcupuncturist and herbalist‘She would come twice a week for acupuncture. I have five treatment rooms and Diana always liked to be in room five, which was the biggest treatment room and very light and airy. Sometimes she would invite two or three friends so they could be in neighbouring rooms and have acupuncture together. The insulation wasn’t very good so if I inserted a needle into her friend she would say, “Ow!” and Diana would hear and shout, “Don’t be such a baby.” ’         Diana hitting Prince Charles over the head with a prop glass bottle - one of many practical jokes she pulledMICHAEL COLEFormer BBC royal correspondent‘Before an official visit to Spain, there had been rumours of ill health and unhappiness. Filming the princess from behind as she walked down a street in Toledo, her shoulders suddenly started shaking as if she was upset and crying. Members of her party went to her. She kept her face from the camera and I reported that something had happened to make her emotional. I was later told that she had seen something saucy in a shop window and had been trying to stifle her giggles. My report that it was something worse merely made her laugh again.’DR JAMES COLTHURSTDiana’s close confidant and old friend‘When she bought her first car, a blue Honda Civic, I went round to Diana’s with my flatmate at about 11pm and put two L-plates on the car and then tried a string of tins together underneath with enough slack for her to get out of the parking space without disturbing the string, so that when she drove onto Old Brompton Road she was trailing a line of tins behind her. That evening she rang up and I said, “How’s your car?” and she said, “My car’s fine. How’s yours?” I moved to the window and saw my car under the streetlight covered in flour with eggs on top. I had to wash it off quickly, because it goes quite hard. That was fairly much Diana’s line of fun. She was great at one-liners, like when we were on a skiing holiday and I fell asleep with my mouth open. Diana said, “Gosh, James would be a real wower in a goldfish bowl, wouldn’t he?” Her way of phrasing things was funny.’         Diana meeting Australian lifeguards at New South Wales' Terrigal Beach in 1988JENNI RIVETTPersonal trainer‘We trained in her drawing room at Kensington Palace which was absolutely huge. Once we were working out on this lovely rug and I said to her, “Don’t you think we should roll it up out of the way as it’s so beautiful?” She said, “Oh no, it’s a present from the Hong Kong government and I can’t stand it!” ’MICHAEL COLEFormer BBC royal correspondent‘There was a huge traffic jam on the Bath Road on the evening of a ball at Osterley House to celebrate the world’s oldest political alliance, that of Britain with Portugal. Nothing was moving as cars tried to turn right. Suddenly, along the grass verges in front of the suburban semis, the Prince of Wales’s Bentley came bouncing along, up, down and across people’s drives, around parked motorbikes, with the Princess of Wales laughing in the back of the car as if on a scary ride at a fairground.’KEN LENNOXFormer royal photographer‘Visiting the Royal Hampshire Regiment in 1988, she clambered into a tank — a bit like the famous Margaret Thatcher shot, but she was wearing a tracksuit and a military jacket. When she came out, she slid down the tank and I was standing right there. She said to me, “Unfortunately I couldn’t find any ammunition”.’JAYNE FINCHERPhotographer         Diana and Fergie prodding a friend with an umbrella at Royal Ascot in 1987‘She used to get the giggles about things. In Australia in 1988 we were at Bondi Beach and we thought it would be the archetypal lifeguard on the beach picture. When we got there all these scantily clad lifeguards were lined up to meet her, but then the sponsors decided their swimsuits were too scanty so they told them to put their tracksuit bottoms on. Of course we were all horrified because that wasn’t going to make a good picture.As they put their tracksuit bottoms on, we said we were going to go on strike and not take any pictures. So when Diana arrived we were making them take their trousers off again and she could see all this going on. When she came to the beach she started giggling and didn’t know where to look. She looked everywhere other than at those scanty swimsuits. She was posing in the middle of them and looking up at the sky. She was really flushed and got the giggles again — she didn’t want to look down.’NISH JOSHIHolistic health practitioner‘Kevin Costner kept calling her asking her to act in Bodyguard 2, a sequel to his movie with Whitney Houston. She laughed and laughed when she told me, “He keeps calling me wanting me to play the person the bodyguard protected.” She thought it was so funny.’SARAH BRADFORDAlso known as Viscountess Bangor, royal biographer‘I always felt Diana was wary of Fergie and yet when Fergie was turned down as prospective lady-in-waiting for Diana because she was deemed “most unsuitable”, Diana was furious.         Diana and Prince Charles at Prince William's confirmation ‘There was always trouble afoot when the two women got together, like on Fergie’s hen night when she and Diana wore grey wigs, dressed up as policewomen and pretended to arrest a “prostitute” outside Buckingham Palace. They were put in a police van and driven down The Mall until one of the policemen recognised Diana. He was so shocked he couldn’t believe it and said, “Oh my heavens, it’s the Princess of Wales!”‘Later they went on to Annabel’s nightclub where they narrowly missed Prince Andrew, but they then succeeded in tricking the policemen on the gates at Buckingham Palace and they shut the gates in Andrew’s face as his car approached. Fearing an ambush, he screeched into reverse. That’s when Fergie wondered if she’d gone too far.‘I’ve not been a fan of Fergie’s and none of this would have occurred to Diana without Fergie’s bad influence. A member of staff said Fergie had her own agenda and used to get Diana into trouble and then disappear.’DARREN MCGRADYPersonal chef‘Because we were a small household it was up to Paul Burrell or me to fill her car up with petrol, because she felt vulnerable at the petrol station. She drove a BMW or a Mercedes. So I would drive out through the gate, the police would salute and I would pull faces. I would fill up the car and drive back but I would notice there were chocolate wrappers in the footwell.‘So while I was cooking her healthy food she was sneaking out and having chocolate bars in the car. Every now and again after returning the car I would say, “Your Royal Highness, here are your keys, but I found these in the car”, and hand her the chocolate wrappers.‘And she would say, “Oh they must be William and Harry’s” and smile. Because she knew that I knew! She liked Drifter bars and Time Outs.’MICHAEL COLEFormer BBC royal correspondent‘It was customary to meet the Press at the start of a royal tour. In the British ambassador’s residence in Washington in 1985, the princess stood in the receiving line as familiar faces presented themselves, fresh from covering the Queen’s tour of the Caribbean. “Now, let’s see all these glorious suntans,” cried the princess in triumph. “Not much work has been done in the West Indies, that’s for sure.” I told her it was rust, not suntan, as it had rained throughout the Queen’s tour. “I am sure someone believes that,” said the princess. “But it’s not me”.’         Diana and Prince Charles share a post-polo kiss. Some believe that she still carried a torch for him years after separating ZANDRA RHODESFashion designer‘I was cycling along to my factory in Hammersmith one day in a horrible polyester knitted hat and an old tracksuit and this very smart car went by with a big window and hats in it. It was a Thursday, Ladies’ Day at Ascot, and these two girls were waving at me. I thought, “Well I can’t know those girls they can’t be waving at me,” so I looked the other way.‘Anyway, later when I was at KP doing a fitting I realised it was Diana and Fergie on their way to Ascot who’d waved at me. Diana said to me, “Are you still riding your bike?” I said, “Oh, yes, yes,” and she said, “I hope it disguises you more than when I go to things!” ’RICHARD YOUNGPhotographer‘I used to go to San Lorenzo restaurant a lot because I knew the owners. I’d be sitting there having lunch on my own — crudites and calamari — and a few times Diana came in to meet friends, and as she walked past my table she’d nick a carrot and say, “Oh, Mr Young, how are you?” ’MICHAEL COLEFormer BBC royal correspondent‘Diana was shopping in Harrods in 1996 wearing the most elegant Yves St Laurent trouser suit that accentuated her height. There had been some photographs of her rapidly growing sons in the papers which prompted me to say, “You’ve certainly bred some height into the Royal Family.” She stopped and said, “And good looks, Michael, and good looks!” She wagged her finger to emphasise the point. She was proud of her Spencer genes and antecedents as a direct descendant of King Charles II.’         Former royal photographer Ken Lennox says 'Diana was a bold girl, and I think Charles found her too difficult'JAYNE FINCHER Photographer‘She was always a bit suspicious when women reporters came along, new ones that she didn’t know. She’d say, “Oh watch that one, she’ll be fluttering her eyelashes at my security staff. And look, she’s got awful shoes from Russell &amp Bromley.” Woman to woman, we’d laugh about that.’JENNI RIVETTPersonal trainer‘I didn’t realise I was supposed to curtsy to her, and one day we bumped into her best friend Julia Samuel in Kensington Gardens and she curtsied to her. I was a bit surprised, and I asked Julia why she was curtsying to her best friend. She said, “I’m not curtsying to her, I’m curtsying to the Crown and so should you.”‘So the next time I saw Diana I apologised and said, “I believe I’m supposed to curtsy to you — so I owe you four years of curtsies.” She said, “That’s why I love you Jenni, because you’re South African and you don’t know about these things. Don’t worry.” She really took people at face value — she used to take off my accent and talk like a South African, and say things like, “Yeeees Jeeeni”. She was very funny.’KEN LENNOXFormer royal photographer‘Diana was a bold girl, and I think Charles found her too difficult. Whereas Camilla was totally acquiescent to everything Charles wanted or said or did, Diana was a young girl with different ideas. If I turned up at something I wasn’t supposed to turn up to, she would point her finger at me and wag it, but it was always with a smile on her face.       ‘She had absolutely perfect manners and a great sense of giggles too. We used to say, though, that when she was upset about something, her laser eyes would be switched on.’MICHAEL COLEFormer BBC royal correspondent‘Although they did fall out from time to time, and were in or out of favour with the Press, Princess Diana and the Duchess of York were friends from way back and Fergie was always up for any devilment that occurred to Diana, like livening up an afternoon at Royal Ascot by poking the royal equerry Major Hugh Lindsay in the back with their parasols when they spotted him walking along to the paddock.’MICHAEL WHITLAMFormer director general of the British Red Cross‘On a trip to Washington about six weeks before she died she invited me to have tea with her. She had the room below mine and one of the staff came and said, “Diana would like you to join her and the ambassador’s wife for tea.”‘So I went downstairs to where her living room was. She was sitting there with the ambassador’s wife, in her dressing gown and with white stuff all over her face. I, of course, blushed and looked incredibly embarrassed, and they thought this was highly amusing and spent the next two hours ribbing me about it — “Come join the girls,” she said. “Come join the girls for some girly chat”.’

title: Shocking moment two year old girl tumbles 10 feet sewer
story: Share this article The shocked mother rushes to the sewer apparently shouting to the workers who immediately rescue the child.According to reports, the girl was rushed to hospital in a state of shock and diagnosed with severe bruises to her right hand. Her life is not in danger and she will get better soon.         Moments beforehand the workmen had left the manhole open at the entrance of a block of flats in Cheboksary         A police investigation is now underway and the men may face criminal chargesPolice have launched a criminal case against the workers.Local Investigative Committee spokesman Oleg Dmitriev said to local media: 'The sewer was left open without a safety fence.'The girl was exiting the apartment block following her mother and fell into the sewer.'We are treating this as work performance that does not meet the requirements for health and safety.'If found guilty the workers face a fine or up to two years in jail. The investigation is ongoing.

title: Premier Inn guest humiliated toilet broke staff gave bucket bath use
story: Share this article          Ms Elder made a complaint to Premier Inn about the lack of a functioning toilet in her roomWhen asked by the Premier Inn social media team for further details Terri wrote: 'My toilet in my room is broken. It was when I arrived. The hotel is full.'A maintenance man came and could not fix it. The assistant manager I spoke to seemed to know there was an issue with my toilet though, which is concerning then why they would give the room out.'I have been offered the bucket, to use a staff toilet one floor away or to maybe move hotels (which was suggested then I was told though they'd all be full due to an event on in town).'I had wine with dinner so can't drive to another hotel anyway.'Surely you cannot accept customers being left all night without the use of a working toilet in their room?'Since lodging a complaint with Premier Inn, Terri has been offered a refund as a gesture of goodwill.A Premier Inn spokesperson said: 'We are sorry that Ms Elder did not have a positive experience when staying with us last week.'We were unaware the toilet did not flush when Ms Elder checked in and did everything we could to fix it once we were made aware.'We also offered a paid taxi to an alternative hotel or use of our staff toilets, as soon as we realised the problem could not be fixed immediately out of hours.'The bucket for flushing the toilet was provided as a temporary measure and last resort overnight.'We have apologised to Ms Elder directly, have refunded her stay and provided a goodwill gesture by the way of an apology for the inconvenience caused.'

title: Over half new homes sold unfair leasehold terms ban
story: Share this article 'The government announced action 18 months ago but too little has changed, and it is clear the worst housebuilders take no notice of ministers.'Their proposals for leasehold reform are too slow, too weak, and overlook existing leaseholders.' Communities Secretary James Brokenshire - who last week repeated the pledge to ban leasehold sales of new-build houses - said: 'I have been clear that exploitative and unfair leasehold arrangements have no place in a modern housing market so we are taking bold action to reform the sector.'We will legislate to ensure that in the future – unless there are exceptional circumstances – all new houses will be sold on a freehold basis, with ground rents in future leases reduced to zero.'Just last week, I announced that we are seeking to vary contracts with developers to ban the sale of leasehold houses, other than in exceptional circumstances, within the current Help to Buy scheme.'         Shadow housing secretary John Healey said government action on leaseholds was 'too slow and too weak'         Communities Secretary James Brokenshire insisted the government was cracking down on 'exploitative practices'

title: Petra Ecclestone sells largest home Los Angeles record 95m
story: Share this article          The largest property in Los Angeles has netted Petra Ecclestone a staggering £27 million profit after she purchased it in 2011. It comes with a number of stunning features such as a solarium and a games room         An overhead view of the stunning gardens at the 123 bedroom property shown to viewers in 2011. It also has a swimming pool and a tennis courtPetra was granted a orce in 2017 after a bitter legal fight over their £5.5 billion fortune, with the couple’s assets including a £100 million Chelsea mansion.Petra, who has three children with Mr Stunt, moved to LA from Chelsea in 2018 to get a fresh start and leave her marriage woes behind.In an interview with W Magazine about the property, the heiress said: 'I was living in an apartment before, in London, so it’s a change. That was 5,000 square feet. Then I moved into our other house in London, which was 20,000 square feet.'She added: 'I know that the house is huge, and yes, it really is quite overwhelming, but with the other houses we looked at that were a similar size to this, you felt like you were in a museum. 'She moved into the sprawling 56,500-square-foot chateau, known as The Manor, but insisted on an extensive refurbishment.The previous owner had a bowling alley, a room dedicated specifically to cutting flowers and even an entire climate-controlled chamber for storing silver, in the property.The house also included a barbershop, multiple gift-wrapping rooms, and a French wine and cheese room, complete with French music and side-walk tables.But Petra was not a fan of the decor and embarked on a huge redesign that took more than nine weeks and required 500 workmen.          Petra took ownership of the home that comes with a swimming pool (pictured) after a chaotic period in her personal life, during the collapse of her marriage to James Stunt         The Manor is the largest home in LA and among the largest single-family homes in the entire country, measuring more than 1,500 feet larger than the White HouseCandyland’s former wrapping rooms have since been swapped out for a hair salon and massage parlor.There’s also a tanning room, solarium and a games room. Rolling lawns, rose gardens, citrus orchards, statues and grandiose fountains all fill out the The Manor’s grounds, which also include a swimming pool, spa and tennis court.It’s the largest home in LA and among the largest single-family homes in the entire country, measuring more than 1,500 feet larger than the White House.Considered to be one of LA’s priciest neighborhoods, Holmby Hills has seen the sale of a number of record-breaking homes in recent years.The Manor is just a stones-throw away from a previous record holder, The Playboy Mansion, which sold for $100 million back in 2016.It will now become the fourth home in the state to top a $100 million asking price, besting the $110 million Malibu beach-front home bought by Peter Morton in April last year.Candyland is also tied for the fourth most expensive home in US history, with a $238 million Manhattan apartment purchased by Keith Griffin topping the pack.The home was initially placed on the market for $150 million in 2014, but after receiving no offers in two years Petra inexplicably upped the price to a whopping $200 million, before lowering her expectations in 2019.The buyer of the mansion remains unknown, but the LA Times reported that the inidual was represented by Beverly Hills real estate agent Jeff Hyland of Hilton &amp Hyland.The home was purchased by Petra from Candy Spelling, the wife of director Aaron Spelling, famed for producing Beverly Hilly 90210 and The Love Boat, died at the Manor on June 23, 2006. He collapsed and died on the property from complications from a stroke he'd suffered five-days prior.         In December 2011, Candy Spelling (pictured), gave a guided tour of the mansion, known as 'Candyland', which was originally purchased by her director husband Aaron Spelling

title: How launch nuclear strike Russia
story: Share this article Goldfein described his next call after the NATO Commander, immediately calling NORTHCOM NORAD commander General Terrence O’Shaughnessy to set into motion the homeland response. Ground-Based Interceptors (GBIs) now stand primed for the incoming missile, with the Pentagon's technology of sensors and targeting technology to seek out the actual warhead from the decoys surrounding it.Goldfein praised the Trump administration for bringing talks about a space force into the open, saying that the military is developing space-based lasers and drones to defend the US from above the earth's atmosphere.The three-pronged counter-attack is then crucially completed by the nuclear-submarines which discreetly launch barrages of destruction from underwater.They are designed to deliver the 'second strike' to hammer the enemy into submission.         A B-2 stealth bomber - they would fly at high-altitude to knock out Russian launch sites and air defense systemsThe purpose of the submarine threat is to warn America's enemies, 'Don't even think about it,' one Naval official told Defense Maven.Goldfein's next call goes out to STRATCOM Commander General John Hyten who will brief Goldfein on how a nuclear attack can be launched as a deterrent.Despite the General laying out the steps as so, Defense Maven quoted him as saying: 'Every one of these missions is no-fail. And every one of these missions needs to be accomplished simultaneously.'Air Force Chief Details US Response to Russian Nuclear Attack - Warrior Maven

title: Tardis house just seven foot wide goes sale 80 000
story: Share this article Due to its size, the house has a galley-style kitchen with modern fitted units. The living room features underfloor heating and a tiled floor.  There is also a loft, which can be used for additional storage. Heating is by means of a log burner in the living room. Unfortunately there is no central heating.           The living room looks out towards the rear of the building and the garden and provides access to the first floor          There is a small extension to the rear which can be used as a utility room, allowing access out to the rear         The constrained dimensions of the house mean the two bedrooms are quite narrow but fairly long         One of the two bedrooms has a sloping Velux window providing plenty of light and making it seem slightly bigger         The bathroom appears to be a basic affair, although the tile work is clean and there is a bath and electric shower         To the rear of the property, there is a sunroomutility room and a large wildflower garden, pictured

title: Shocking moment boozy speedboat driver 39 RAMS luxury motor yacht
story: Share this article The v-shaped hull of Kennedy's vessel rides up the back of the motor yacht and bounces off its outside seating area section before slapping back down on to the water. The woman tells the man, who is thought to be driving, to call the police as Kennedy circles back round and looks poised to batter their boat once again.However, as he closes in, he looks up from over the edge of his craft's raised bow and waves at the pair who he just plowed in to.         Kennedy was arraigned on Monday on charges of operating while intoxicated and malicious destruction of propertyBut as he turns to drive away, he sticks up his middle finger, prompting the woman to yell 'you're going to jail a** hole!' at him. Kennedy was arraigned on Monday on charges of operating while intoxicated and malicious destruction of property, according to WXYZ Detroit.The couple on board the motor yacht were not injured but claimed that their boat suffered extensive damage.         The woman tells the man, who is thought to be driving, to call the police as Kennedy circles back round and looks poised to batter their boat once again - before waving at the couple and racing awayMan accused of ramming boat on Lake St. Clair charged with OWI

title: Amsterdams woman mayor plans red light district overhaul
story: Share this article The plans included four main scenarios: ending street window displays, closing down city centre brothels and moving them elsewhere, reducing the number of city centre brothels and stepping up the licensing of window workers.The scenarios, drawn up in a report titled 'The Future of Window Prostitution in Amsterdam', also included a broader proposal for an 'erotic city zone' that would have a clear entrance gate, similar to a system used in Hamburg, she added.Those options will be presented to residents and businesses at town hall meetings this month before one chosen and put to a vote in the city council later this year, Halsema said.         Mayor of Amsterdam Femke Halsema poses for a portrait in Amsterdam last monthPast efforts to control the red light district have faced opposition from sex workers and businesses involved in the lucrative trade.The mayor said there were no plans to outlaw prostitution outright.'We legalised prostitution because we thought and still think that legal prostitution give a woman a chance to be autonomous, independent. Criminalising prostitution has been done in the United States, I think, makes women extra vulnerable.'The changes had three main aims, she said, to protect women from degrading work conditions, to cut crime and to revive the 500-year-old neighbourhood which, along with Amsterdam's canals, is part of a UNESCO world heritage site.One sex worker and member of PROUD, a union defending the prostitutes' interests, told Reuters the women there were facing increasingly disrespectful behaviour.'The tourists don't know how to behave themselves in this area,' said the women who declined to give her name. title: Heavily pregnant Labour MP Ellie Reeves faces deselection bid
story: Share this article A Labour Party source said 'no motion has been formally moved or tabled' and such a motion would have 'no formal standing' even if one was passed by local party activists.The deselection bid has prompted senior Labour MPs to give their backing to Ms Reeves. Harriet Harman said: Ellie Reeves elected in 2017 is not going to be deselected by UK Labour in 2019 while 5 months pregnant. We are not going to let it happen. Full Stop!The Labour former frontbencher said up and down the country there are women being pushed out of their jobs when they’re pregnant and that Labour is there to stand up for them.          Ms Reeves reportedly asked Jeremy Corbyn's office to intervene but the request was apparently dismissed         Harriet Harman, the Labour former frontbencher, has vowed to defend Ms ReevesThe row came after a poll revealed heavy support among party members for Mr Williamson to be reinstated. Some 61 per cent of readers of the left-wing website LabourList backed reinstating him. However, in the same poll of more than 10,000 people almost three quarters (74 per cent) said that Labour should introduce an independent complaints procedure after criticism of the current party process.  A slew of shadow Cabinet ministers criticised the decision last week to reinstate Mr Williamson, including frontbench allies of Mr Corbyn including Rebecca Long-Bailey, Angela Rayner and Jon Ashworth.The party bowed to a widespread revolt on Friday by halting plans to restore the party whip.Mr Williamson had been let off with a warning after a pattern of behaviour that included saying the party was 'too apologetic' about cases of Jew-hate in February.EXCL Pregnant Labour MP facing deselection threat for signing Chris Williamson statement | PoliticsHome.com

title: the new me halle butler review
story: The New Me is a depressing novel. It’s about a depressed young American woman called Millie, who works in a depressing temp job, while spiralling into even greater depression at the prospect that the job might become permanent. It is also bleakly funny: “I think I’m drawn to temp work for the slight atmospheric changes,” Millie writes. “The new offices and coworkers provide a nice illusion of variety. Like how people switch out their cats’ wet food from Chicken to Liver to Sea Bass, but in the end, it’s all just flavored anus.”Butler’s debut, Jillian, also used the office as a backdrop. Such a setting could be considered brave for a novelist: most jobs are tedious, to complain at length about how tedious they are can be even more so. Nor, in these precarious times, is the “I hate my job” lament in short supply. Yet the generation that graduated into a recession has also been sold the lie that you have to “love what you do”. How to square that with the monotonous pointlessness of most office work? Butler paints it as a kind of spiritual death: “Back at my desk I sit and slowly collect money that I can use to pay the rent on my apartment and on food so that I can continue to live and continue to come to this room and sit at this desk and slowly collect money.”Her coping mechanisms are alcohol, back-to-back episodes of true-crime TV, deadpan humour and delicious hostility. Of an obnoxious colleague: “I fold my hands in my lap and re-create him in my mind … his young girlfriend’s jaw setting compulsively when she smells his breath, his father’s dying words (I wish you had been less of a dick) …”Millie is from the now well-established school of the privileged antiheroine. She is not quite as loathsome as Ottessa Moshfegh’s protagonist in My Year of Rest and Relaxation, though her parents pay for her apartment and she is a horrible snob, tearing down an acquaintance for using “utilise” in conversation (“it’s a real first-gen-college-grad kind of word, like your parents are small-town conservative Christians who didn’t have any books in the house”). When the reader starts to feel compassion for Millie, it feels like a literary feat. That place of tension between the expectations of privilege and the colourless reality of life in an advanced service economy is fertile territory for art and comedy. Capitalism makes people behave odiously, the office becoming a backdrop for petty acts of psychopathy, revenge and narcissism, but opting out, or trying to, comes at a price. It’s the only reality we know. And that is a depressing thought. • Rhiannon Lucy Cosslett’s The Tyranny of Lost Things is published by Sandstone. The New Me is published by Orion (£8.99).
